As the name implies, their are rock, scissors, and paper cards. In addition, there are dynamite and double take cards, all of which come in assorted colors.

The short of it is, think Rock Scissors Paper meets Uno.

24446.name: Busy Busy Builder
24446.description:
From the box:
Busy Busy Builder is a dress-up game for boys and girls who love building things! Be the busiest builder in town by collecting your own matching colored set of tools: screwdriver, hammer, wrench, nut and bolt. Don't work too fast because you might land on a Sore thumb. the first player to collect all of his or her tools and the Tool Belt wins the game.

Contents:
4 Moving bolts
4 Screwdrivers
4 Hammers
4 Wrenches
4 Nuts
4 Bolts
1 Sore thumb
1 Screwdriver spinner arrow
1 Tool Belt
1 Game Board
Instructions

Ages 3+

24447.name: Twisted Fish
24447.description: Twisted Fish is a variant of Go Fish. Instead of pairs, however, players are attempting to get groups of five - and memory plays a much larger aspect to the game, as well as a bit of bluffing. A few special cards are thrown into the mix to shake things up.

24448.name: Three-Player Crokinole
24448.description:
Three-Player Crokinole is a specially designed Crokinole board that works only with three. This game cannot be played on a standard board and thus is considered to be a different game.

The three-player board has markings that divide the board into three areas (vs four for a standard board), and repositions the pegs around the center to make these three positions optimal for shooting. Three players play independently (no partners), and when shooting either other player's disk must be hit for your shot to be legal. Scoring is done on a differences basis as in the original game, except often two people will score per turn as a result.

24449.name: Five-Hole Crokinole
24449.description:
Five-Hole Crokinole is played on a specially-drilled board and was popular in Canada in the late 1800s. The board is sized like a standard board, but in addition to the center hole it has a hole in the center of each 10-point area.

Play is similar to standard Crokinole, except that any disk pocketed in one of the 10-point area holes is removed from play and counts -10 points. This allows for both offensive attack and makes tricky shots more risky. As a result, scoring is usually more chaotic and variable.

This game can be bought in five-hole form, or often a standard board can be retrofitted to make this version. That retrofit is almost always one-way, though!

24450.description:
Viking Waves takes place in the areas raided and conquered by the Norwegian and Danish Vikings during the early Viking Age. It's a game primarily for two players, though limited solitaire play is also possible. The various Viking chieftains rarely fought each other directly, so players compete indirectly.

The game is divided into three phases, each of which involves dozens of raids/attacks and which can be played as a separate game (or all three can be played sequentially as a campaign). In Phase 1, which lasts from 792 until around 834, each raid involves a few ships and lasts only a few days. In Phase 2, from around 834 to around 850–864, raids are larger. In Phase 3, from around 850–864 until 879, the goal is conquering land with armies and creating permanent settlements.

In the standard game, each player represents an ever-changing group of Norwegian and Danish chieftains. Optional rules allow for the historical division of territory between Norwegian and Danish groups, allow for limited combat between the two players, and provide for solitaire play.

One twelve-page rulebook
Two 8.5" x 11" maps
One Player Display
342 counters
24450.name: Viking Waves

24451.name: Inword
24451.description: Players try to guess the word after they given a cryptic clue and the Inword, a series of consecutive letters within the word they are trying to guess. In turn, each player tries to guess the other letters contained in the target word. Players take turns as guessers and host.

24452.name: Giant Dice
24452.description: A set of giant dice are rolled and depending on the type of arithmetic operations allowed in the game, players do math involving the numbers to match corresponding numbers on their sheet. The first player to get a row of 4 or 5 numbers wins.

24453.name: Jutland
24453.description:
Jutland: 2 Player Card Game sim of the great Sea Battle of WWI. German vs British Fleets. Each side gets a Unique deck. Played in 6 "Historical" turns. Players try to get the highest scoring hand each turn. Good Filler game. Complete Ruleset and Cardset at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Jutland.html

24454.description:
Oscar the Grouch, Cookie Monster, and Ernie face off in this slightly atypical memory matching game. Each player's goal is to have the longest chain of tiles at game end.

There are two notable differences from most memory matching games.
1. Rather than two tiles being matched to each other, this game has players matching tiles to the symbol resulting from a spinner
2. Instead of ending when all tiles are matched, the game ends when the fourth stop tile is drawn.

Twenty-nine tiles are laid face-down on the play surface. These tiles interlock like puzzle pieces, making a chain of tiles when credited to a player. The game includes a spinner with, six spaces. Three of the spinner spaces show one shape (triangle, circle, or square), while the other three spaces have two shapes. Players take turns using the spinner, and then selecting one tile.

If the tile says "free spin", then the tile is added to that player's chain, and the player immediately takes an additional turn.

If the tile matches the shape(s) on the spinner, then the tile is added to the player's chain of tiles, and that player's turn ends.

If the tile does not match the shape on the spinner, the tile is shown to the other players, and then returned face-down to the available tiles.

If the tile says "stop", then it is attached to the top of the spinner. When the fourth "stop" tile is drawn, the game ends.
24454.name: Sesame Street Simple Shapes Game

24455.name: A History of Chess
24455.description:
H.J.R. Murray's classic work on the history of chess includes chess variants from around the world and throughout history.

Originally published in 1913, it was recently reprinted and is now available again.

Contains history, development and the rules of nearly every Chess variant prior to 1900. A Classic!

Republished by Oxford University Press (available from Amazon et al)

24456.name: Sesame Street Dominoes
24456.description:
Sesame Street Dominoes is played like the classic game Dominoes with variations for ages 3 and up and ages 4 and up. The dominoes are thick cardboard pieces with the faces of popular Sesame Street characters in the center surrounded by 4 different colors to the top, bottom, left and right.

In the 3 and up game, players match the faces of Sesame Street characters. In the 4 and up game, players match colors.

24457.name: Rotten Wood: Horror Rules Mini-Game #1
24457.description:
There's something rotten in the woods tonight - and it ain't your franks and beans! The dead are on the move, and it's up to you to put a stop to it. So grab your shotgun, fire up the chainsaw and get ready for some good old-fashioned zombie-hunting... Horror Rules style!

Horror Rules Mini-Games provide all the fun and mayhem of Horror Rules without the rule crunching. Included in this Mini-Game is everything you need to play, including Paper Forge Minis, maps, weapons and item counters and more - just print and go. Use the more than 60 Horror Markers to simulate the challenges, dangers, perils and scares of the zombie-infested woods, and change the mix to make a different game every time. You pick the size, scope, number of pieces and even the goal of each game.

The Horror Rules Mini-Game system is flexible and fully customizable, great for veteran gamers, kids, families, parties or as a way to introduce new players to the wonders of gaming. Play it solo or with others in cooperative or head-to-head play. Games take as little as 5 minutes and can easily be played during a coffee break or lunch time. With endless variations and Styles of Play, you can create whatever gaming environment you like, from a simple tabletop boardgame to a full-blown RPG.

Rotten Wood is packed with full-color gaming aids that bring the zombie nightmare alive. Inside you'll find:


Paper Forge Character Minis: 6 complete Characters, each with Stats and Skills



Paper Forge Bad Guy Minis: a full page of fearsome zombies, complete with Stats and Powers



Map of Rotten Wood: 8 pages of maps; use them alone or together to build a master map



Horror Markers: More than 60 counters packed with challenges, hazards, weapons, items, perils and frights



Rule Spins: A dozen Spin cards to add endless variation and spice to your Mini-Game



Bad Guy Power-Ups: Jack up your Bad Guys with these disgusting but guaranteed-to-please boosters



Rules: All the instructions you need to make the mayhem happen


Paper Forge Character and Bad Guy Minis are fully compatible with Horror Rules the RPG, with Stats and Skills printed right on the back. Use them to play the Mini-Game, the full RPG or any other modern roleplaying game. The 8-pg map can be used in HR as well or whatever game you choose.

Included in this download are two complete sets of rules, enough to fit every taste:

The Basic Rules are a quick, simple board game with fast setup, plenty of action and thrills and tremendous variation. Use the Horror Markers to make every game exciting and different. Play by yourself or with a pal.

The Skirmish Rules are full-out tabletop war. Pit your heroic and resourceful characters against the not-so-heroic and ravenous zombies in a knock-down drag-out no-holds-barred free-for-all in Rotten Wood. Skirmish Markers include standard Horror Rules weapons with full Horror Rules stats. Requires two to play.

24458.name: The Bird-Table Game
24458.description:
"Find out how to identify the birds in YOUR garden!"

In this game, players move around the board collecting points by correctly identifying and answering questions about wild birds that might be found in British gardens. Although prior knowledge helps, it's not essential: the game is designed to help players develop their bird-related expertise.

24459.name: Racecraze
24459.description:
"RACECRAZE: A Strategic, Fun-Filled Racing Game!"

A Nascar-like themed racing game from a small publisher. The mechanics of this game are simple: "Qualifying" position is based on random card draw. Each turn, roll three (standard) dice, and optionally roll two more "special dice" (33% +3, 33% -3, 33% take a card). Move your car on the track (16 spaces to 20 spaces around from inside to outside track; no track "choke points") by the total amount. Cards either move car forward, backward, or force player "into the pit" before proceeding. Player turn order is re-ranked each turn by position+laps, and each race (of 5) ends after a predetermined number of laps.

Each player is awarded a number of points at the conclusion of each race based on finishing position. Winner has the most points after the fifth race.

24461.name: Tank Killers
24461.description: Two player card game. Simulates a battle between two tank formations during WW2. The current version of the game has decks for: Germans, British, and Americans circa 1944-5. Rules and card set available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/TanK.html

24462.name: High Iron
24462.description: High Iron is a very early Winsome game with an extremely limited print run. It is Colorado-based train game with idea that were further and better developed in later Winsome titles.

24463.name: Gametasia
24463.description: GAMETASIA CARDS 71 boxed cards featuring 47 Extractors, 9 Utopians, 9 Treasure Cards, and 6 Rules Cards. 2 to 4 players.

24464.name: Royal Poker Dice Game
24464.description:
Royal Poker Dice Game is a game of Yahtzee using the entire deck of cards.
Five 12-sided dice use all 52 cards of a normal deck plus 8 stars (wild cards). Every possible poker hand can be made.
For one or more players.

Contents: Five 12 sided Dice, Dice Cup, Score Pad, Felt Mat, Convenient Carry Case.

A less expensive "travel" version is available which eliminates the felt mat, changes the shape of the dice cup to oblong, and replaces the carry case with a fabric drawstring bag.

24465.name: The World's Greatest Travel Game
24465.description:
Two containers hold 25 3 dimensional one-inch cubes each. The cubes have pictures numbered 1-5 on all of their sides except one, which holds a large red X on it.

The object of the game is to to acquire five X's in a row, like a bingo game. However, this game is much more complex in its variant forms.

Initially, the base setup is for each person to turn all of their picture cubes to the 1 numbered picture--the easiest items to spot. Goal: Spot five items or a picture of each of the five items, revealing 5 X's which form a straight line.

Rise To The Top: In this variant, each person does not reveal the X upon sighting a 1 numbered item. Instead, the person will turn the number two picture to the top. This continues until the number three item is sighted, and the X is turned up. The first person to five X's in a row wins.

Go For Points: Similar to Above. Attach a time limit or mileage limit to the game. At game end, total the numbers of the photos as points, scoring each X as a 10 point item. Highest total wins.

This can be played as a solo variant, with a solo player trying to accomplish point goals per number of miles, or trip duration.

The Handicapper: In a child versus adult game, using the base game rules, the adult would adjust their numbered pictures to a 4 or 5 starting point.

One Block At A Time: Start with all X's showing. Each person will take out the first block in their container. As soon as either player sees one of the five items, they replace the block in their container with the picture showing of the item spotted. They then move on to their next block, until all 25 blocks are gone through.

The game ends when one person is done with all 25 blocks. Total all points of exposed pictures.

Get Nasty: Each player arranges the cubes of their opponent, using the number five pictures of each number (5-5's, 5'4's, etc...) and arranges them in a way which is thought to be most difficult to achieve 5 in a row. Same as base game otherwise.

Composite Game: Start with all number 1's. As you see each item, turn that cube over to X. When you get five X's in a row, turn that row over to the number two pictures. Continue with the same goals, turning five in a row over at a time until you get the five numbered pictures. The first person to turn over five number five pictures, revealing the final X's, wins. A complicated variant, indeed.

24466.name: El gran juego de Conocer la Ciencia
24466.description:
A Spanish Trivial pursuit clone, Science themed.
The 5 categories are:
- Nature
- Space & Technology
- Characters
- Science history
- Other Sciences

24467.name: Post Office
24467.description: This is a game for 2 to 4 players. The instructions say that it should be played by girls and boys together. Each player gets a particular color to start on. That color is used later on. A girl starts the game! There are spaces on the gameboard such as First Class, Air Mail or Special Delivery. When a player lands on one of them the player picks a card and reads it aloud. The card will list some kind of stunt that must be accomplished in order to score points. If a partner is needed to accomplish the stunt then the player spins a spinner, the male who has that color representing him is the girls partner for the stunt. There is a time limit to accomplish each stunt. The stunts are childish (this game is appropriate for perhaps 8 to 12 year olds). Some examples of stunts that need to be done; You and your partner eat a potato chip at the same time and immediately whistle Yankee Doodle. First one to whistle the first line wins the points. Or Standing back to back with your partner, remove his or her jacket or sweater and put it on yourself without turning around. The successful completion of a stunt in the given time limit results in winning a certain amount of points. First player to reach 500 points is the winner.

24468.name: Skipper: Barbie's Little Sister
24468.description: This is a game about Skipper (Barbie's younger sister) and her horse Prince. Appropriate for 6 to 10 year olds. It is a simple roll and move game. The object of the game is to be the person who reaches the BEST IN SHOW square at the center of the board while holding; a card for your horse Prince, your tack, your riding habit, your club pin and 25 points . Players roll and move around the board. On some spots on the board you will be given the opportunity to enter the SHOW RING and score points for how your horse does. Those points can be traded in for some of what you need. Necessary money is accumulated as you go around the squares on the board.

24469.name: Spion
24469.description:
Spion (=Spy) is a 2-player strategy game with an unusual victory condition: you must find two hidden points on the opponents half of the gameboard. These hidden points are secretly marked on a paper copy of the gameboard; a whole pad of copies is included.

The gameboard has 2 halves of 64 hex-fields each and the armies of the 2 players contain 6 defenders, 4 little spies and 2 big spies. The defenders are single colored, while the spies show both colors, because they can be turned over when captured! Defenders cannot leave their half of the board. Spies can move everywhere and they are therefore needed to find the 2 hidden points.

24470.name: Flip & Flop
24470.description:
The board is 8x8 in size and every player has 4 playing pieces. Object of the game is to move 2 of the 4 pieces on the opposing side of the board.

The name of the game comes from the moving mechanism of the playing pieces: they can move 1 field in all 4 directions, but they are flipped over every time when they move (I guess they "flop" when moving to the left or right side).

All playing pieces are numbered from 1-4 on one side and from 5-8 on the other side. Since the pieces are always flipped over, the value of the pieces is changing with every move and it needs much thinking in advance to find the best moves.

Another problem is, that the pieces should always look in the same direction. To assure this, each piece has 2 dots on the front and 2 on the back, but when comparing the pieces on the game-box with the ones included with this game, it is obvious, that this designing problem is not solved very well.

24471.description:
Taken directly from the translated rules

"Murmel Fiff" is the name of the friendly marmot, who organizes a fun apple harvest with its friends: On the marmot hill stands a strange apple tree, whose bright glowing fruits have different colors-exactly like the marmots. Each one especially loves the apples of its color and wants to add these four to the stock in its own hole.

(I love this bit)

Whoever will manage it the first? Whoever gathers diligently at the beginning; and in the second phase, with the luck of the dice and foresight, gives away apples, pinches them and brings them back to safety, which influences the exciting race.

In any case you have only won, if the marmot has all four of its own apples-and only those-in its own hole and then also places itself in it!

Ages 5 and up.
24471.name: Murmel Fiff

24472.description:
From the rules:
Take home your new best friend! In Adopt-A-Dog, every player gets a chance to adopt and nurture a lovable puppy. Once players sort through the dogs' items and collect 3 of their dogs' favorite toys, players can take home and care for their new pets!

For ages 3+

Adopt-A-Dog is a VERY simple set-collection and trading game for very young children. It plays fast and is easy for young children to learn. I would not suggest this game for children over 6 as they will get bored very quickly.
24472.name: Adopt-A-Dog

24473.description:
From Rick Thornquist (BoardGameNews.com)

This is a card game where players are promoting musical acts.

There are seven cards representing seven musical acts which are arranged in a column on the table. You get a hand of cards and each card corresponds to one of the acts. You start with one card face down in front of you. There is also a face-up pool of cards plus a draw pile.

On your turn, you turn up your face down card and play it beside the corresponding act. You then take on card from the pool and one from the deck. Finally, you place a card face down (which will be played on your next turn).

When one act gets three cards beside it, play stops for the 'Hit Parade'. Starting from top to bottom, each act moves up a number of spaces equal to the cards played beside it (this can push acts it passes down the column). The cards played are put into the pool and play continues.

The game ends when the deck runs out. You get points for the cards left in your hand - if you have cards for the act at the top of the column you get five points each, for each card for the second act you get four points, etc. Whoever has the most points at the end wins.
24473.name: Megastar

24474.name: YARR!
24474.description:
YARR! is the newest game set in the 'Age of Piracy.' All the things you've wanted in a pirate game including:

6 separate nationalities to play.

18 distinct captains to choose from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.

5 different ships all with varying stats for speed, attack and defense dice, crew capacity and more: Schooner, Sloop, Barque, Frigate and Galleon.

Faction levels allow for you to attain ranks of nobility like Count and Duke, or remain a pirate!

Sword fighting, Ship-to-ship combat, Treasure Maps to collect, Magical Items from remote Islanders to enhance your abilities, Political Actions (cause nations to go to War!), specialized cannon shot and swordfighting tactics and so much more! Heck, it even has the Lucky Parrot!

YARR!!!

24475.name: Balam
24475.description:
The boards represents various sites of a thick forest of Yucatan, in 8th century, on which the players, who play as competing kings, are building cities.

The goods produced in these cities by Maya people must permanently be distributed between taxes - which allow growth - and sacrifices - which allows to increase power.

At the end of the game, the most prestigious king becomes the first emperor of Yucatan.

Game components :

33 Site tiles (the tiles, once juxtaposed, constitute the game board)
1 board score track tile
72 Katun cards (Katun is a 20 years-long period. While players are drawing the cards, Katuns will follow one another, sometimes positive, and sometimes catastrophic.)
4 individual King cards (They allow to store the pyramids and the goods of the king and they remind rules)
52 large pyramids in 4 colors (indicating which player owns the site)
64 small pyramids matching the large pyramids (indicating which player has the commercial control of the site)
99 building tiles double sided, of 4 types (8 different buildings : villages/garrisons, palace/temples, market/storage, grounds of pelote/observatories)
82 good tokens of 6 types (30 yellow corn, 10 brown cocoa, 8 blue shell, 8 green jade, 16 black obsidian, 10 red prisoner) ("village" buildings produce goods and wars bring back prisoners)
4 6-sided dice (used to solve conflicts).

24477.name: Chuckers
24477.description: Each player's side of the board consists of 9 panels in a 3x3 grid which all start as one player's color (orange or yellow) but become the other player's color when the panel is flipped. This can be done by landing a marble on a panel, causing the panel to flip and change color. Players attempt to get 6 panels in a row of their color by quickly and repeatedly launching marbles onto the game board.

24478.name: Robo Bash
24478.description: A free game included in the Dork Tower #14 comic book. Each player controls a RoboBasher (mechanical vehicles with differing attributes in Firepower, Armor, and Speed), moving it around an arena trying to destroy all the other RoboBashers. During each round, a player can use a limited number of "Power Dice" to boost the values of their RoboBasher's attributes.

24479.name: Make-A-Scene
24479.description:
Info from back of box:

Set the scene for laughter and fun with Make A Scene, the uproarious Category Drawing Game! Start with a deserted main street, or an unused barnyard, or maybe a bare bedroom. Now draw as many items you can think of into the scene before time runs out. Here’s the catch - each item must begin with the same letter and must really belong in the scene.

The drawing is exciting, but get ready for real laughs when it comes time to justify your choices. Go ahead... explain what the MERMAID is doing on MAIN STREET next to the MAILMAN and the MUTT!

Scoring:
A team receives one point for each item drawn and two points if the item is unique (drawn by only one team). After 4 rounds, the team with the highest score wins.

For 2 players or 2 teams.

31753.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set

boardgamehonor.9283: 2007 Årets Spill Best Family Game Nominee

24480.description:
Die Säulen der Erde / The Pillars of the Earth is based on the bestselling novel by Ken Follett and the 2006 game in the Kosmos line of literature-based games.

At the beginning of the 13th century, construction of the greatest and most beautiful cathedral in England begins. Players are builders who try to contribute the most to this cathedral's construction and, in so doing, score the most victory points. Gameplay roughly consists of using workers to produce raw materials, and then using craftsmen to convert the materials into victory points. Workers may also be used to produce gold, the currency of the game. Players are also given three master builders each turn, each of which can do a variety of tasks, including recruiting more workers, buying or selling goods, or just obtaining victory points. Getting early choices with a master builder costs gold, as does purchasing better craftsmen. Players must strike a balance between earning gold to fund their purchases and earning victory points.

Expanded by:


The Pillars of the Earth Expansion Set (which include the Expansion Cards in some editions)
The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Cards (which are included in the Expansion Set in some editions)
24480.name: The Pillars of the Earth

24481.description:
This is a game of sentence construction "cunningly educational!"

The object of the game is to reach the "circle 9" by discarding all his cards. Players advance on the board by making sentences with the Action Dragon cards.

How to play:
Each players draws a card when on their turn, to advance, the player must set on the table a series of cards that contain at least the number of cards indicated on the next circle you want to reach. This series must also include at least one card of each of the colors indicated by the triangles on the next circle. The series of cards (image) makes up a sentence that the player must say out loud.

There is a variant for youngsters.
24481.name: Action Dragon

24482.name: Healthy Habits
24482.description:
From Dr. Toy:

"Players will have a blast moving around the game as they are the game pieces. The set comes with 30 cards that use the topics of nutrition, exercise, sleep and personal hygiene. The game doesn't have a board. Rather, the cards can be set up in any pattern you wish, winding around the room, under tables, in and out of doors, etc. The children move forward by rolling the large foam dice included in the game. For example, "You rode your bike, move ahead three spaces.", and "You sat in front of the TV set all day and didn't get any exercise, move back to the square." This educational game is a great way to promote the values of good nutrition, exercise, healthy sleep habits and personal hygiene."

24483.name: Wackee SIX
24483.description:
From the publisher's site (www.Wackee.com):

"OBJECT OF THE GAME
To get the most points and to be the first player or partnership to 'Go Out' and call “Wackee SIX!” This is done by playing out all 12 of the main cards originally dealt to you. While that is being done, you want to turn your remaining deck as fast as you can, and play as many cards onto the crazy piles in the middle of the table as you can. This is where most of your points will come from. This game play gets really "Wackee", because no one takes "turns", everyone just plays at once.

What is in the box?
6 decks of cards, each with 2 WILD cards and 52 cards numbered 1-13 in 4 different colored suits. There are 6 different colors on the back of the decks; one color for each player or team.
An optional playing field mat is included in case you don’t have a table and to make it easier to learn."

24484.name: Disorder
24484.description:
Disorder is a word game that takes wits, strategy and a bit of bluffing. Each round, players must add one card to the board. They can choose it to be a specific letter, or they can opt to make it wild! Either way, they have to make sure it fits, because sooner or later, somebody is going to have to face the music... do they add another letter and risk it all? Or is it time to throw down the gauntlet and challenge? These letters can form lots of different words... or can they? Is it really a word or are people bluffing? Anything can be made out of Disorder, but if it happens on your turn... you better be able to come up with the right word!

Contents:
100 Disorder cards
1 game board
50 scoring chips
EZ-Play instructions

24485.name: Take Your Best Shot
24485.description:
Get ready! You only get one chance to get it right in this game... Each round, one player must reveal a card with three words on it. They'll read a question and then you... act fast! Toss the correct colored ball into the Determinator. Get it right and get it first and you'll get lots of points. Get it wrong and... well... just don't get it wrong! First person to cross the finish line on the score board wins! But remember, you only get one guess each round, so take your best shot!

Contents:
EZ-Play instructions
15 guessing balls
5 scoring tokens
440 cards
game board

24486.name: The Fund-Raising Game
24486.description:
snip from rules:

"Object: The object of this game is to set a fund raising goal and raise that amount of money. There are intervening factors, such as luck and timing, that will affect the raising of your dollar goal. However, the bottom line is cash on hand.
The game is not intended to be competitive. The main objective is to provide discussion among players on various aspects of fund raising."

The game consists of a game board, 4 tokens, 2 dice, 25 each of Risk and Opportunity cards, a pack of Fund raising Goal and Funds Balance cards, play money, Rules booklet and ANSWER KEY.

Yes, ANSWER KEY! Basically, this is a game designed to teach fund raising skills to young 'wannabe' fund raisers. So the cards have real questions on them. For instance, "15. To generate significantly more income from mail appeals, a priority would be to . . . A. Mail more times in a year B. use segmentation data to specialize appeals. C. purge lapsed donors to trim your mailing expenses."

And in case you really wanted to know, according to the answer key, the answer is . . . B

24487.description:
Set Sail!
To start the game, the player who does the best pirate impersonation goes first! Move around the board trading, scavenging and battling for treasure. You can pick up Quest Cards on the way, they can help you search for fortune or even bring disaster by sending you off course! Once your ship is laden with treasure, sail back to your port to unload your cargo. The first pirate to safely store 20 treasure points wins!

The game has a board with 6 harbors and Tortuga Island, Isla Cruces and Isla de Muerta.
The speed at which you can sail across the board is controlled by cards. These cards are either red (normal pirates) or black (cursed pirates) and have a number 1 to 3. The same cards are used to determine your attack value : highest color minus lowest color.

The aim of the game is to collect 20 treasure points, where treasures are available in a range of 2 to 5.

Re-implements:

Buccaneer
24487.name: Pirates of the Caribbean Buccaneer

24489.name: Drag Racing, The Board Game
24489.description:
Publisher's descriptions:

"Drag racing fun for the entire family with DRAG RACING-the Board Game. Don't let rain dates get you down. Now you can drag race anytime, anywhere. In the trailer or at home on the kitchen table, drag racing action like you have seen at the track. Our game is played with dice and charts. We've included plastic game pieces in the shape of dragsters, funny cars, and pro stockers. You can match race or qualify a 16 car field and run through eliminations. But watch out for the racing gremlins. Blown motors, broken transmissions, tire shake, or smoking the tires are just some of the problems you might run into on our track."

". . . you can race in a Top Fuel Dragster, Nitro Funny Car, or in a Pro Stocker."

"Want to be the number 1 qualifier? Run in 'power' for a shot at 'low e.t.' Watch out though, you might smoke the tires, grenade a motor, or get out of the groove. Tire shake or a broken blower might also do you in. With a little luck you can make a clean pass on your way to victory. Great fun for the entire family. You can re-create your favorite drag racing event or start your own 'fantasy' series with "DRAG RACING - The Board Game."

"There are three ways to play the game.
1. Match Racing (two out of three) is the quickest.
2. Running a set field of 8 or 16 cars through eliminations.
3. Qualify a 16 car field then run through eliminations."

"The Drag Racing Game Co. brings drag racing to your table top with a new 3-D game board. Our new drag strip game board is easy to read, has full length guardrails, and comes in full color!!!"

"Game comes complete with 3 piece game board, 12 plastic game pcs.(cars), 4 die, ladder charts to track eliminations, and all the charts you need to race down the quarter mile."

24490.name: Alphacadabra
24490.description: Try to locate the hidden word of your opponent, as in a game of Battleship. Then try to find what is that word by naming letters, as in a game of Hangman.

24491.description:
Escape! Expand! Defend! Conquer!

Your civilization is living peacefully in a solar system whose sun is steadily approaching Supernova. You must abandon your planet and fight for a foothold in a new solar system before your home world is destroyed. Over the next millennium, you will have to learn new technologies - Weapons, Shields, Communications or Engines - to aid in your quest for survival. Earn income by mining moons and discover alien races on new planets, earning you valuable bonuses. You need to plan carefully, balancing your rate of expansion with defense, as you must guard your claimed territory and fend off other civilizations to protect what you have rightfully won.

Supernova is a board game with a unique card-based battle system and inspired artwork by Mike Doyle. Players vie for control of space as well as the unstable sun, imminently approaching Supernova. Players acquire points by owning planets and moons, earning income, and by placing tiles to expand their empire. The modular game board of this wonderful new space design offers a different experience with each play. The player with the most points when the sun goes Supernova is proclaimed the winner!
Supernova is #3 in the Valley Games Modern Line
24491.name: Supernova

24492.name: Don't Quote Me: Sports Illustrated Edition
24492.description: Players attempt to move their piece around the track the fastest, answering questions from five different categories from the realm of sports: Team, individual, vintage, names & numbers, and sidelines. Players may have to identify quotations, pick three correct answers out of four, list items, and answer other trivia questions. Covers a wide range of sports questions, including even TV shows, movies, and obscure sports.

24493.name: Galactic Expanse: Starship Battles
24493.description:
Publisher's description:

This is an exciting card game of strategy, tactics and chance in deep space combat between the warring space-faring humanoid species who all feel that the galaxy is not big enough for all of them. Their starships combine the awesome firepower of powerful particle accelerator beam energy weapons and devastating hyper-speed torpedoes for close combats and long-range raids by smaller ship-borne strike craft and the deadly mercenary shadowcraft. The four different species can ally in various patterns, resulting in different combinations in different games, or they can operate alone. Players determine when and where to seek battles; to launch distant raids or close with the enemy for battles within star systems or nebulae. The side that scores the most victory points by vaporizing enemy ships and winning star systems wins the game. This is an entertaining and fun card game where every playing is different. Playing time is one to three hours.

24494.name: Mergers & Acquistions: The Hostile Takeover Game
24494.description:
In this game, you become a business owner attempting to increase your company's profits through hostile takeovers of other companies. You have investment money of 1.2 billion dollars to finance your coming mergers and acquisitions.

Your goal is to buy other companies at a relatively low price compared to their value. If you control that company, your company's profits will increase as well.

The basics of the game:

There is one more business than there are the number of players, each with different company values. Players each have 14 chips with investment values printed on them (4 X 5, 3 X 10, 3 X 50, 1 X 100, 1 X 200, 1 X 300, 1 X 400). They (usually) secretly place these one at a time near a business they wish to invest in. The 2nd, 5th, and some later investments made in each company are made publicly (everyone sees the investment amount).

Players gain control of a company by having more invested in the company at the end of the game than any of the other players (and get more points for having more than all the other players combined). The tricky part being that a player will almost always need to have control of 2 or more business to win, but there's not enough businesses to be able to do so easily, so each player *will* have to out-invest another player, which involves bluffing them as to where your high-value investment chips are.

Each player also chooses an 'investment strategy' card at the beginning of the game, and plays it at some point during the game, changing things like making the value of a company halved, or giving them extra shares in a company, etc.

24495.description:
Also known as 'Conquerors of the Eastern Country'.

A 2-6 player game set in feudal Eastern Japan(2-12 players if combined with Heroes of Western Japan).

Meant to appeal to fans of the many feudal multi-player games that came out in the 80s in Japan and of 'eurogame' fans wanting something quicker.

It ends up playing like a fast-paced 'History of the World'. Not in the 'multiple epoch' sense (the game does not cover multiple eras), but in the sense that attacks are done by 'expanding out' and attacking adjacent territories with newly hired units, and a placed unit is never actually moved.

Each player controls a different daimyo, each having tis own unique (and fairly important / useful) power.

There is a deck of Fate cards that give valuable bonuses and abilities to the players that get them. Players bid each turn on the right to get 1st pick of the available cards that turn.

Money is received from territories, varying in value from 1 to 3 per territory.
Gold is spent buying the 3 main types of armies can be hired to attack with, bidding for card choice, and paying to maintain the effects of 'continuing cards'

Victory is done by getting a point per territory held at the end of the game, with bonus points (or penalties) given for tea bowls placed in various territories throughout the game. The catch is that only the player who placed each tea bowl knows its value (and thereby, how important it is to get/retain control of that territory).

It's a DTP game, meaning that you need to stick the counters on your own blank counters.

This can be combined with Heroes of Western Japan to get a larger game covering all of Japan.
24495.name: Conquerors of Eastern Japan

24496.description:

A 2-6 player game set in feudal Western Japan (2-12 players if combined with Conquerors of Eastern Japan).

Meant to appeal to fans of the many feudal multiplayer games that came out in the 80's in Japan and of 'eurogame' fans wanting something quicker.

It ends up playing like a fast-paced 'History of the World'. Not in the 'multiple epoch' sense (the game does not cover multiple eras), but in the sense that attacks are done by 'expanding out' and attacking adjacent territories with newly hired units, and a placed unit is never actually moved.

The catch is that only the player who placed each teabowl knows its value (and thereby, how important it is to get/retain control fo that territory).

24496.name: Heroes of Western Japan

24497.name: Hockeyswap!
24497.description:
(From the Back of the Box: Build a hockey dynasty through ruthless trading and brilliant coaching. Blow away the competition during regular season games and qualify for the playoffs. Win the playoffs and become League Champion!)

Players are coaches of hockey teams that fill up their rosters by either a blind draw of player cards, or coaches can draft players based on an $8,000,000 salary cap.

The regular season games are determined by drawing discs out of a bag, and comparing either the offensive or defensive ranks of the players to determine who scores a goal, or goals, for that period. Follow the supplied season schedule, or create one of your own, and play through the regular season and the playoffs to determine the champion.

24498.name: L'Enclos
24498.description: An abstract strategy game first published in Vers l'Éducation Nouvelle n° 402, April 1986. Each player has three sheep: on a turn, a player moves one sheep to an adjacent hex and then places one barrier between any two adjacent hexes. The first player to be blocked in and unable to move loses.

24499.name: Flibid-e-Jib
24499.description:
What's a Flib? What's a Jib? And why am I trying to lose all my cards again!

Flibid-e-Jib is the wacky new card game that's not only hours of fun for the whole family, but educational too! (sshh! Don't tell the kids!)

For 2-6 players age 7 and up, Flibid-e-Jib is an addictive way to make a rainy day go by quickly! Perfect for the cottage or trip.

Instructions in French and Spanish.

24500.name: About Nothing
24500.description:
About Nothing, The Absurd Game of Useless Trivia is the latest game from Brainy Day Games.

Here's some of the nothing you'll find inside:
- Absurd World Facts
- History of Plumbing
- 80's Cartoons
- Ancient Sports
- Crazy Inventors
- Fast Food Facts
- Sesame Street Trivia
- Word Origins
- Parts of the Body
- Elvis Knowledge

1800 Questions.
2-6 Players.
For ages 7 and up.
Lots of useless trivia.
